sentence: Stocks were mixed at Tuesday's close with the Dow returning earlier gains to close lower, the S&P 500 unchanged but the Nasdaq Composite closing at another record high and in the plus column for a sixth straight day.

Gains in the healthcare and internet sector kept the tech-heavy index afloat while the other benchmark averages struggled for direction on the eve of President-elect Donald Trump's press conference and start of Q4 earnings season.
Stocks were modestly higher at the open, buoyed by bullish labor market data, and a greater-than-expected gain in November wholesale inventories and sales.
A slight correction in the dollar was also supportive, especially for multi-national corporations that rely on a weak dollar to maintain an advantageous trade position.

Mid-morning the benchmark averages rotated off their session highs in sympathy with a reversal in crude futures, exacerbated by losses in component stocks Proctor & Gamble ( PG ) and International Business Machines ( IBM ), both of which lead Dow decliners.
The Dow flip-flopped between the plus and minus column but ultimately slipped into the red at the close.

In corporate news, shares of Yahoo ( YHOO ) were higher after its CEO, Marissa Mayer, announced plans to resign from the company's board if, and when, the company's internet assets are sold to Verizon ( VZ ).
The remaining assets, which include its holdings in Alibaba ( BABA ) and Yahoo Japan, will be renamed Altaba, of which Mayer will remain CEO.

European shares were mostly higher with the UK's FTSE-100 setting its longest-ever winning streak with eleven straight higher closes, buoyed by a sagging British pound that has helped bolster UK multinationals.
Wednesday's economic calendar is light with only the Atlanta Fed business inflation expectations survey, and the weekly Energy Information Administration status report.
Later in the afternoon, New York Fed president William Dudley will give a speech about banking regulations.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) BIOC (+77.45%) Secured an in-network provider agreement with Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Texas

(+) ILMN (+16.60%) Introduced the NovaSeq series, Q4 revenue projected at $619 million, upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank of America

(-) HGG (-40.46%) Reported preliminary net sales for Q3 below expectations, comp store sales down, expects non-cash charges

(-) VNCE (-13.95%) Expects full-year revenue and earnings at or below the low end of earlier guidance

(-) WMB (-10.74%) Priced 65 million share offering at $29 per share, downgraded to hold from buy at Jefferies
